title: 72 Days On, Postpaid Mobile Services Restored In Kashmir But No Internet Yet
text:
72 Days On, Postpaid Mobile Services Restored In Kashmir But No Internet Yet

72 Days On, Postpaid Mobile Services Restored In Kashmir But No Internet Yet

Postpaid mobile phone networks were restored in the Kashmir valley on October 14 after a 72-day blackout but the internet remains off-limits to the region's seven million-plus people.

Access to mobile networks in the Kashmir Valley were snapped in early August citing security concerns as the controversial Article 370 of the Indian Constitution that granted special status to the state of Jammu and Kashmir was partially scrapped by the Indian parliament .

A youth looks on as another one speaks on a mobile phone in Srinagar on October 14, 2019. AFP PHOTO

The easing on Monday covers around four million post-paid mobile phone contracts, but only for calls and text messages. The internet is still unavailable on both cellphones and fixed line networks.

Landlines were already restored previously. According to AFP, residents say connections are erratic.

Mohammad Akbar, a businessman, told AFP in the main city Srinagar that he was pleased that mobile phones were working again, but had harsh words for the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

"Mobile phones are a commercial service that we pay for, not a favour," he said. "They slash our basic rights and then ease things as favours and call it normalcy."

Having mobile phones "is something completely normal in most countries. But here in Kashmir it is a big deal", law student Mashouq told AFP.

"And it can be taken away at any time," he added.

Kashmir reportedly has more than 2 million pre-paid connections but they are still to be restored.

Residents use mobiles phones in Srinagar on October 14, 2019. AFP PHOTO

Authorities fear that insurgents and separatists will use the internet to provoke protests in the region that have the potential to morph into large-scale street demonstrations.

Residents appeared relieved on Monday after facing difficulties during the long communications embargo. But the region continues to simmer with anger, reported news agency Associated Press.

“It is a relief,'' Mohammad Akram, a trader, told AP. He was, however, quick to add how Kashmiris are expected “to thank the government for giving them basic amenities.''

Women look on as they use mobiles phones in Srinagar on October 14, 2019. AFP PHOTO

Many also expressed their angst at the situation, with some saying that the past two months were akin to living in the Stone Age without lines of communication.

“Thank you, India. You have finally decided to partially restore our digital rights,'' Sameer Ahmad, a college student was quoted as saying by AP.

“When will you restore our political rights?''

People were seen using mobile phones on roads, market places, inside offices and banks talking to each other.

With Inputs From Agencies
